awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cognitive Mechanisms of Early Math Learning - Improving Outcomes by Harnessing Multiple Memory Representations
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

The study will investigate the processes that connect gestures and mathematics learning. Gestures are an important yet under-investigated aspect of mathematics teaching. They can influence students' memory and understanding of mathematical representations. The series of studies will examine students' learning of the concept of mathematical equivalence by testing instruction that incorporates commonly used verbal explanations and gestures. Mathematical equivalence includes understanding the meaning of the equal sign and determining if two expressions are equal. Second and third grade children will be participants.  Of particular interest in the studies is the influence of gestures on preexisting knowledge of procedures, how gestures support learning beyond emphasizing information and direct learners' attention, and the creation of procedural knowledge. 

The series of experimental studies will examine the mechanisms that connect gestures and procedural understanding of mathematical equivalence. The studies begin in the first phase with examining how gesture is connected to procedural knowledge of mathematical equivalence. Subsequent studies investigate how gesture functions as a mechanism for learning beyond emphasizing or directing attention to relevant information. Data collected will students' responses to equivalence problems and eye tracking data to follow whether students are looking from one side of the equal sign to the other. In the second phase of the work, the studies will examine how gesture has beneficial effects on learning more generally in mathematics. Working memory will be assessed in order to examine the role of gesture across different individuals. Fraction tasks will be used to examine the generalization of the previous results regarding gestures to other mathematics concepts.

por.por_cntn:
When teachers accompany their mathematics instruction with hand gestures, children learn and remember more. Gesture improves learning of a variety of mathematical and scientific concepts (Cook, 2011; Cook, Duffy, & Fenn, 2013; Goldin-Meadow & Alibali, 2013). However, to harness the potential power of gesture to enhance student learning, researchers and practitioners need to understand how it works. In this project, researchers from the University of Iowa and Michigan State University worked together to investigate how instruction with gestures affects learning, and which students benefit the most from its use.

In one line of work, we looked at how a person's verbal and visuospatial working memory capacity is related to their ability to learn from instruction that includes gestures. In the first study, we found that college students with stronger spatial working memory benefited more from instruction that included gestures, while those with stronger verbal working memory benefited more from instruction that did not include gestures. In the second study, we tried to replicate these findings using different materials, but we found that individuals with stronger spatial working memory benefited more regardless of whether the instruction included gestures or not. Further research is needed to understand the differences between the results of these two studies.

In a second line of research, we examined whether using gestures during instruction leads to learning that is more resistant to interference. We conducted a study with second and third-grade children where they received instruction in mathematical equivalence using videos with or without accompanying gestures. After the instruction, the children were given problems to solve that were either similar to the problems they were taught (interference) or different (control) to test the role of gestures in overcoming interference. The results showed that gestures helped with learning, but the effects varied depending on children's prior knowledge and not on whether children had solved potentially interfering problems. For children who used an Add-All-Numbers problem-solving strategy prior to instruction, instruction with gesture enhanced learning. In contrast, for children who used an Add-to-Blank problem-solving strategy before instruction, instruction with gesture did not improve learning.

In a third line of research, we looked at how gesture affects visual attention during problem-solving using eye-tracking technology. We found that children who were taught with gestures during instruction subsequently looked more at the answer blank when solving problems compared to children who had been taught without gestures. Children who are taught with gesture may be more likely to integrate the answer blank into their problem representation. This may be especially important for children who are using an Add-All-Numbers problem-solving strategy that does not consider the answer blank and may help explain why these children are more likely to benefit from gesture.

We also applied machine-learning techniques to analyze the eye-tracking data and found that there were differences in fixation patterns during problem-solving after learning with gestures. These findings suggest that gesture may also influence higher-order aspects of attention, in addition to increasing attention to the answer blank.

Taken together, these studies provide preliminary information for teachers, technology designers, and other instructional content creators that can be used to support the design of effective instructional materials. Results have been disseminated through conference presentations, invited lectures, and publications.

The findings from this work have important implications for understanding how gestures help with mathematical learning. While gestures have the potential to support learning, they may not have the same effect on all learners. Thus, the benefits of gesture may not stem from a general mechanism such as improving attention or engagement that would apply to all students regardless of their prior knowledge or cognitive abilities. Instead, the results suggest that the effect of gesture on mathematical learning vary depending on the student's prior knowledge and cognitive abilities. Thus, a more nuanced and individualized approach may be necessary to fully harness the power of gesture to improve student learning.

The project also provided opportunities for teaching and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students. It also generated a dataset from eye tracking that can be used for further research on the relationship between gestures and attention. This dataset will be accessible for students who want to explore and test hypotheses about the role of gestures and attention in learning.
